The interesting part about the jewelry is that the jeweler takes actual leaves and coins from all over the world and dips them in gold, they truly are very creative and unique pieces. Seasonal Whispers is a jewelry company out of New York that carries a wide range of bracelets, necklaces and rings. All of the jewelry contains Swarovski crystals and made of stainless steel so that they never tarnish. The jewelry can be described as very fun and hip. Rochelle’s has a very pleasant feel to it and you feel as though you are entering a dance club in LA. The floors are painted gold and dance music is always playing with cutting edge trendy clothing, and very pleasant sales associate waiting to greet you and help you with your purchase. Rochelle’s is not for the faint of heart, it is a high fashion store with edge. Rochelles Beach is the sister store of Rochelle’s and it is located next door to Bruno’s café. This store has something for everyone and of range of age groups shop here. This store is a blend of bathing suits, sandals, inexpensive jewelry and sunglasses, hats, women and men’s Sperry’s, Pure Sweaters, Watch Hill tee shirts and sweatshirts, casual dresses, printed tanks, shorts, and tee shirts. The Pure Sweaters are hand knit one of a kind shawls and sweaters with the trademark big buttons that Pure is known for. These shawls and sweaters come in a variety of colors ranging from pastels to bright shades of red and blue. The extensive range of bathing suits in Rochelle’s Beach is all mix and match. This is a very nice feature because most women are not the same size on the top and bottom and this has proven to be a very successful tactic when selling bathing suits. Rochelle’s has a very friendly and helpful staff that is always ready to lead a helping hand when trying to find the perfect swimsuit or dress.

Monelle is one of only two stores open during the winter. This is a tiny, up-scale boutique, offering designers such as Juicy Couture, Molly B, and Kate Spade. If youre looking for a prom dress, you might want to try this store for a unique find. Monelle is right across the street from the Watch Hill Yacht Club, and a stones throw from Napatree Point.

Special Tees is a great place to get cheap, reasonable souvenirs from Watch Hill, a nice memorabilia from a day in Watch Hill. The sweatshirts and tee shirts make for nice gifts and most of the store has very practical clothing that will not go to waste. A sweatshirt is great for the cool nights in Watch Hill while enjoying popcorn from St Claire’s Annex and checking out the magnificent sunsets.
Gabrielles only sells infant and childrens clothing. High in price, but really cute!

Only open in the summer through September. There is usually an annual sale at the end of the summer, in preparation for the off-season. Christina’s carries the line Free People and Lily Pulitzer. This is a relatively expensive shop carrying preppy and conservative clothing. The clothing is usually very bright with over the top prints. This shop definitely has a specific audience it is targeting. The clothing is very reminiscent of the vibe that Watch Hill gives off. Collared shirts and respectfully lengths skirts and dresses compose a good percentage of Christina’s. Christina’s has many loyal customers and clothing that is of very good quality. You get what you pay for and many of the pieces can be considered timeless (if this is your style), so if you choose well you can definitely get your moneys worth!
This is the perfect store for teenage girls. Seaport Surf sells brand name bathing suits, clothing, and purses.
Located right across the street from the carousel. Only open May through Columbus Day. Carries beachwear, shoes, jewelry, and beach toys.

Open May through October. This is a great used book store offering antique books, especially about fishing and boating. Book and Tackle also carries postcards with local images, which are great for tourists visiting Watch Hill. There is a wide variety of childrens books sold here, too.
Davis Gallery, 2766 Route 6, +1 508-349-0549. Sandpiper Gallery, Commercial St., +1 508-349-9500.
Unique boutiques offering beautiful clothing for both men and women. Everything is a "must have". If you are wearing something from Blue1, consider yourself fashionable
A popular clothing store for men which specializes in suits and more formal attire.

It contains contemporary clothing for men, women and children. The store features brands such as Cambio, Free People, Michael Stars, Luna Luz, Red Engine, G-1 Paper Twill, Vineyard Vines, White and Warren, Kinross Cashmere, Magaschoni, Grainne Co., Hanky Panky, Lucky Jeans, Smathers Branson, Laurie B, Lilla P, Grassroots and Tribal. Mustique has clothing for a range of ages and body types and their friendly, experienced staff is happy to assist you with any of your shopping needs. Mustiques staff will even gift wrap your purchase if needed. They are open year round, 7 days a week and offer a great selection of clothing for any season
Located right next to OSuzanna, before the Beach Bakery
Offering gorgeous shoes and handbags for women, Shoe Inn is a great store to shop for the newest and most popular shoe styles. Sandals, pumps, uggs, boots and more.
Clothing for young, chic women. Features great, unique styles
Bold, beautiful pieces transition seamlessly from day to evening. With a simple adjustment, the same earring worn with jeans and a tee shirt can become a dramatic black tie chandelier earring.

Trolley Street in Jane Lew. Mouth-blown and hand-pressed stemware, barware, bells, decanters, bubble balls, brandies, hurricane shades, decorator vases, bud vases, candlesticks, candleholders, votives and decorative marbles. You can watch the glassblowers at work weekdays before 4 pm.

499 US-33 E. Open 9 am to 5 pm Monday through Saturday, and 11 am to 4 pm on Sunday. Specializing in hand-crafted and mouth-blown "old world" apples and ornaments, with over 500 traditionally produced soda-lime crystal products.
In Alum Bridge. Glass artwork produced from 95% recycled glass, including a line made from recycled Budweiser beer bottles.

Fresh food, gift shops, galleries, antiques and restaurants, housed in and around two market houses - an 1853 cast iron columned market house (the only one in the country) and an 1890 brick market house.
A renovated building with a three-story atrium in downtown Wheeling, housing retail shops, galleries, historic exhibits, and working demonstrations by local artisans.

Route 88 N, +1 304-243-4000 or +1 800-624-6988. Seven gift shops, including Carriage House Glass (the areas largest selection of West Virginia decorative glass), Gourmet in the Gardens (gourmet and regionally produced food products) and the Palm Room seasonal plants and fresh flowers, herbs and hanging baskets).

Winonas historic downtown hosts a variety of interesting architectural styles...including Italianate, Queen Anne, Victorian, Egyption Revival...the list goes on. The citys Heritage Preservation Commission and Visit Winona have walking and driving tour brochures, cassettes, and mp3s available to assist in exploring downtown. Be sure to visit Levee Park, and talk a walk on Third Street from the Courthouse to Watkins, then head back west on Second Street. It is also a nice walk from City Hall west to the Courthouse on Fourth Street. Sandwiched between downtown and WSU is a wonderfully walkable historic residential neighborhood along Seventh Street from Franklin to Huff. Youll find interesting spots everywhere.

Most of the retail development of the big-box type occurs along or near this highway which traverses Winona east-west. In and around Riverbend, under Sugarloaf, are Target, Wal-mart Supercenter, and Fleet Farm, as well as a variety of smaller, mostly chain stores. Furthur West, past the lakes, are K-Mart, and the Winona Mall, which, despite its name, includes very little shopping. Then comes the area around Hy-Vee Grocery, which has many smaller businesses, particularly fast-food places. Nearing Goodview, youll encounter another cluster of stores and restaurants where the highway intersects Highway 14/Pelzer Street, which include JC Penney, and Shopko. Unless you like Big-box retailing, Id recommend sticking to downtown.
Located downtown at the corner of Central Ave. and 3rd Street NW/SW. Large selection of antiques.
As with the rest of Florida, there are no shortage of antique shops and Winter Haven will not dissappoint.
Specializing in jewelry, furniture, and Victorian lamps and glassware.
Nearly 10,000 square feet of every variety of antiques.

Located in the same building as the public library. Charity bookstore to support the library with donated books and volunteer staff. About 2/3rds of the books are non-fiction and there are 2-3 sections half off rotated weekly! Almost every book is under $5 with lots of $2-3 books! Moderate selection but with such great prices, its definitely worth a look when in town.

Located downtown. Typical used bookstore with a large selection and reasonable prices. Theres only one larger bookstore in the county, but about half their titles are serial romance/sci fi and a very small selection of non-fiction.
The weekly Farmers Market is held every Thursday 8AM-3PM at the Trailhead Park (611 3rd Street NW). All varieties of fruits and vegetables, especially ones in season.

Located on the west side of US 27 about a mile south of the Cypress Gardens Blvd intersection and just a short distance out of town. Typical flea market with a fresh produce section, although some of the vendors purchase from wholesalers and arent selling the local-grown stuff youll find at the Farmers Market.
Homemade crafts, flowers, patchwork purses, and more.
Art gallery by Florida artisans. Paintings, prints, sculptures, figurines, jewelry, and more.
Art gallery with art, prints, porcelain, jewelry, stained glass, and more for sale.
All merchandise has a "natural" bent but relatively low prices compared to the Ahwahnee Gift Shop. Low visitation to this store makes it desirable for quiet shopping.
Serving as a "camp store", you can find gifts as well as numerous items to make camp life easier.
The largest store in Yosemite, with the largest grocery selection as well. If you need something for your visit, check here first.

Store for the famous nature photographer, also has unique items, and one of the most diverse book selections in Yosemite. Not only do they offer a variety of affordable Ansel Adams Special Edition Prints, but other great selections from landscape photographers of Yosemite. Also unique selection of Native American and contemporary jewelry, and handcrafted pottery. Best for book shopping after the Yosemite Valley Visitor Center Bookstore. Offers a 10% discount for Yosemite Conservancy donors. Store is regarded as the photography "experts" of Yosemite.
One of the two camping goods stores in Yosemite Valley.
Extremely similar to the Curry Village Gift Shop. Caters mostly to Lodge guest, camp 4 campers, and tour groups.
Located in the Degnans building in Yosemite Village, the store specializes in environmentally friendly products.

Two sister stores located inside the Ahwhanee Hotel. The Gift Shop has mostly high-end merchandise (including some of the best jewelry in Yosemite), and the sweet shop sells sundries, food, and more inexpensive items. The Sweet Shop also sells postage stamps.
Best described as a combination between Curry Gift and the Village Sport Shop.
The best sport shop in Yosemite, and one of the best rock climbing gear stores in the world.
Servicing the southern end of Yosemite, this store as groceries and gifts for local campers and Wawona Hotel guests
Well visited by long-distance hikers, as the PCT and the JMT go right by the store, it has camp supplies, gifts, and snacks.
Snacks and gifts for Mariposa Grove visitors. Located near the entrance to the Grove.

One of the few gas stations in Yosemite, it has merchandise you would expect to find in a well stocked mini-mart, but also includes camp supplies. Gas Pumps remain open all year, but store may close in winter.
Home of the TM mountain school, smaller version of the Curry Mountain Shop.

Housed in a turn-of-the-century commercial block at the corner of East Huron and Oak Streets, Old Editions Book Shop and Café is one of the largest antiquarian bookstores in the United States. Three full floors of used rare books, original art and prints, historical documents, collectible magazines and other memorabilia are available to guests of Old Editions for purchase or simply to be browsed through. A small café is available as well. Old Editions Book Shop and Café is a member of the International League of Antiquarian Booksellers and of the Antiquarian Booksellers Association of America.

The Buffalo Christian Centers on-site bookstore offers a wide range of Christian books including print and electronic Bibles, study guides, Christian history, health and self-help books, childrens and young adult literature, Spanish-language books, greeting cards, and music. A selection of apparel is also available, from religious-themed T-shirts to ministers robes, as well as accessories and church supplies from Bible covers to offering bowls and anointing oil. The Center Bookstore is also the only Buffalo-area distributor of religious education materials by Urban Ministries Inc. and the Sunday School Publishing Board.

In 2012, local artist Gary Trella transformed a rundown storefront on the edge of downtown into this charming gallery and store. Since that time, the Elmwood and Tupper Gallery has served as a small but vital member of Buffalos growing art scene, linking the nascent arts district on the 500 block of Main Street with the larger, more well-established community in Allentown. The motto here is "its got to be wild", and that emphasis on unusual and eye-catching aesthetics is evident in the wide array of old and rare paintings, prints and photos, vintage furniture and toys, and early- to mid-20th Century antiques and collectibles that can be found at the Elmwood and Tupper Gallery. The humble, shopworn ambience of the exhibit space lends it a scruffy charm that was described in Buffalo Rising as a "comfortable, lived in vibe where all people are welcome" that "sort of reminds author of the movie Alices Restaurant." Best of all, if youre in town for an opening, you might catch an open-mic performance at the gallerys small soundstage.

Main Street Studios is the brainchild of local artist Erica Zilbauer, who operates the facility in a beautifully renovated building on the up-and-coming 500 block of Main Street. The ground floor is a free gallery where local artists display and sell their works, while the second story consists of studio space available for rent. Main Street Studios also offers workshops and classes for those interested in art.
Founded in 1940 at the corner of Washington and Seneca Streets, at what is today the site of Coca-Cola Field, Tent City is now located in the historic Perron Building in the Theater District.

The Queen City Gallery is operated by photographer Michael Mulley, whose other space, the College Street Gallery, can be found in Allentown. The gallerys mission, according to its website, is "Celebrating the Architecture of Buffalo"; accordingly, the Queen City Gallery is filled not only with Mulleys work, but also photography and works in other media by a bevy of local artists, with an accent on vintage and contemporary depictions of Buffalo and Western New York. Books and prints are offered for sale at reasonable prices.
At the Market Arcade; Metro Rail: Fountain Plaza

One of the founding linchpins of the growing arts community centered around the 500 block of Main Street, the Brian Garman Gallery features large-format photographs with an accent on historic and contemporary images of Buffalo and Western New York. Visitors to Buffalo who are in the market for a decorative item for their home or office can scarcely do better than the prints that are for sale here.

J. Christian is a brand-new fashion boutique offering up stylish ladies clothing in an upscale environment in the Theater Districts majestic, historic Market Arcade building. Rather than focusing on one particular area of fashion, owner Jaime Hargrove sells clothes and accessories in a wide variety of styles and for all purposes—and does it well; theres great stuff in here for great prices (customers especially rave over the excellent selection of formalwear and the $5.00 jewelry table). Aside from that, business attire, chic casualwear, and a variety of other accessories including shoes, hats, and handbags are available at J. Christian.
At the Market Arcade; Metro Rail: Fountain Plaza

Located (appropriately enough) in the Buffalo Niagara Medical Corridor within easy walking distance of Buffalo General Hospital, Buffalo Scrubs is Western New Yorks 1 dealer of high-quality professional medical apparel. Scrubs, lab coats, shoes, and accessories are available in a wide range of styles and brands, with free office consultations, on-site fittings and delivery services provided.

Tent City is one of Buffalos foremost purveyors of activewear, work clothes, and surplus military uniforms. Camping supplies, work boots, winter coats, and apparel from brands like Timberland, Nike, Dickies, Carhartt and Columbia can be found at Tent Citys outlet in the heart of the Theater District.

This brand-new consignment shop, situated in the Pierce Building next to Midway Jewelers, was founded by owner Althea Little as a way to get rid of the old clothes shed collected or had given to her over the years—and its expanded to include an array of clothing and accessories that emphasizes upscale items such as beautiful ladies dresses, fur coats, luxurious jewelry, high-end suits, jackets and other menswear, and hats, handbags, shoes and accessories. The clothing selection at Altheas walks the line between upscale conservatism and urban sass. This is the only consignment store in downtown Buffalo, and its owner was lauded in a write-up in Buffalo Rising for her commitment to the incipient revitalization of the Main Street retail district that had previously been hanging by a thread—so this place deserves your business.

Former Indonesia Stock Exchange trader Novi Paluch has guided Sasmita Batik Indonesia from relatively humble beginnings as a stall at the West Side Bazaar, to a quick ascent into part of the growing wave of retail tenants that have returned to the historic Market Arcade building (and downtown in general). As can be inferred from the title, the stock in trade of this cute, brightly decorated little shop is an exciting and colorful array of fashions, jewelry and loose batik cloth that ably reflect the beauty and culture of Southeast Asia. As well, Sasmita stocks a modest range of accessories, home decor, kitchenware, and unique gifts of the same ilk.
At the Market Arcade; Metro Rail: Fountain Plaza

DC Theatricks is a full-service costume company specializing in custom-made mens period suits and uniforms for sale or rent. Not surprisingly, DC Theatricks does an especially brisk business around Halloween selling literally hundreds of custom-made costumes for adults and children, as well as wigs, makeup, accessories, costume kits, party supplies, decor, and other such goods. DC Theatricks manufacturing department also takes online orders for shipment anywhere, and wholesale pricing is available to qualified purchasers.

The New Era Cap Company—the exclusive manufacturer and marketer of caps for all Major League Baseball teams and their minor-league affiliates, as well as a licensee of apparel for the NHL, NBA, and over 200 colleges and universities nationwide—has been headquartered in Buffalo since its foundation in 1920. At its flagship store on Delaware Avenue, in the former Federal Reserve Building, shoppers can choose from hats representing just about every professional sports team imaginable. As you can imagine, caps for local teams such as the Sabres and Bisons dominate the selections at the store, as well as the New York Yankees, who also boast a loyal following in Buffalo.

Newly moved from the Elmwood Village to the beautifully restored Hotel Lafayette, this lovely clothing boutique is the brainchild of Ali Eagen, who springboarded from New York Citys Fashion Institute of Technology to a rising star in the design industry in Columbus , Ohio and then back to her hometown of Buffalo. Upscale ladies clothing is the name of the game at Made by Anatomy, with a stated goal of helping women express their unique sense of identity through fashion. To that end, the showroom features two collections of made-to-measure designs conceived and constructed on-site by Eagen herself, as well as a carefully-selected array of pieces by local designers chosen with a view to an up-to-the-minute fashion style, an impeccable quality of handiwork, an ethos of sustainability and environmental consciousness, and support of the local fashion community. Custom-designed bridalwear is a specialty at Made by Anatomy, with staff on hand to help customers every step of the way in conceiving their own wedding dresses and bridesmaids gowns from a wide array of fabrics, colors, necklines, sleeve lengths, and other embellishments.
At the Hotel Lafayette; Metro Rail: Lafayette Square

Scherer Furniture is Buffalos oldest furniture store, operating since 1897 in the same handsome four-story brick block at the corner of Genesee and Oak Streets, across the road from the lovingly restored Genesee Gateway row. Even as similar businesses fled for the suburbs, the loyal customers of Scherer Furniture have continued to travel here from all over the region to purchase the quality products sold in this showroom. Those products include solid oak, cherry and hardwood furnishings for every room in the house from renowned manufacturers such as Statton, Wesley Hall, Lexington, Colonial, and Hallagan, sold at reasonable prices with delivery and setup included. Free parking is provided.

Founded in 1892 and run by four generations of its eponymous family, Tiftickjian Oriental Rugs is one of downtown Buffalos longest-standing businesses, not to mention by far Western New Yorks largest and best-known dealer in fine Oriental rugs. That uncommon longevity is probably creditable to the second-to-none care taken by the Tiftickjian family of their customers—buying an Oriental rug is a complicated process that requires extensive knowledge of what youre buying, and the staff here is not only knowledgeable but also trustworthy, even to the point of allowing customers to "live with" the rugs for a while in their own houses before making a final decision on whether to purchase. As for the merchandise itself, a dizzying variety of rugs and carpets are available, from hand-weaved antiques from Persia to high-quality modern rugs. As well, Tiftickjian offers first-rate cleaning, repair and appraisal services for your rug.

Located in the Brisbane Building on newly revitalized Lafayette Square, New Generations is a friendly neighborhood shop that does it all—not only do they sell a wide range of rings, earrings, bracelets, charms, timepieces and other jewelry items in gold and sterling silver, but the store provides complimentary gift wrapping and engraving, and will adjust and replace watchbands and change watch batteries while you wait. The friendly and knowledgeable service at New Generations is matched by amazing prices—customers speak again and again of spending less than half what they would at other stores for items that are of respectable quality.
At the Brisbane Building; Metro Rail: Lafayette Square

Melting Point Jewelers is the place where owner Diane Von Heckler handcrafts personalized custom-designed gold and platinum jewelry for a growing legion of loyal customers—designs which usually include the diamonds and other precious and semiprecious gemstones that Melting Point sells. Melting Point will also appraise, repair or restore your old jewelry or watch, or remount gems from your old piece into a completely new setting.
Diamond Cutters of Western New York

Diamond Cutters of Western New York began in 1984 as a small brokerage serving downtown Buffalo, and has since grown into one of Western New Yorks largest and best-regarded purveyors of wholesale diamonds, selling its products nationwide. "To go to a more direct source, youll need a miners hat", so the slogan says, and indeed, Diamond Cutters of Western New York are able to offer customers unthinkable deals on diamond jewelry by cutting out the middleman, traveling the world to carefully hand-select loose diamonds, which are cut and polished by the two award-winning gemologists on staff, mounted into a selection of lovely contemporary rings, earrings, pendants and other pieces by Diamond Cutters own goldsmith (a selection of other lines of jewelry designs, including Cordova, Prima New York, and Vanna K are also available), and sold directly to the customer. The friendly and talented staff can even help you custom-design your own jewelry! To top it all off, Diamond Cutters of Western New York offers a 30-day exchange policy on all jewelry, lifetime diamond upgrades and cleaning and polishing, and free appraisal.
At the Ellicott Square Building; Metro Rail: Seneca

Midway Jewelers is located in the Pierce Building on Main Street, in the heart of the Theater District. This longtime downtown institution buys and sells gold and diamonds, and also offers a variety of other jewelry including rings, earrings, and mens and womens watches.

Since 1960, Woyshners Flower Shop has provided friendly service to residents of the nearby suburb of Lackawanna , and in 2012, the newest location of this well-loved Western New York business became one of the first retail tenants to move into the newly restored Hotel Lafayette. Woyshners staff boasts experience that other Buffalo florists can only dream of—its founder perfected his art in top schools of floral design in places like Holland and Vienna and for many years did double duty as supervisor of the floral displays at the White Houses formal events—and this expertise is on full display at their airy and impeccably decorated Hotel Lafayette digs. Delightful bouquets and potted plants are displayed in specialized walk-in coolers and in the store itself, with artfully prepared floral arrangements, vases, greeting cards, and gifts. Thankfully, despite the new upbeat trendiness that has come with their move to downtowns hottest new retail destination, Woyshners hasnt lost the personal touch that has ensured their success for the past half-century—far from the haughty or halfhearted customer service that plagues other flower shops in the area, general manager David Keller and his staff go the extra mile in ensuring that his guests receive not only high-quality floral arrangements, but the kind of respectful friendliness that would keep customers coming back to any store.
At the Hotel Lafayette; Metro Rail: Lafayette Square

A multiple-time winner of the "Best Florist" category in Artvoices annual "Best of Buffalo" poll, Maureens is a European-style "pick your own" flower market, whereby customers can buy flowers by the stem and create their own personalized bouquets. Maureens also offers wholesale flowers direct to the public, and happily supplies flowers for weddings, funerals and other special events.

Winner of multiple awards in Buffalo Spree magazines annual "Best of Western New York" feature, City Wine Merchant was described in that publication as having "one of the most discriminating and thoughtful wine selections Western New York has ever seen". City Wine Merchant prides itself on tasting and carefully selecting every vintage offered for sale in their store, with a goal of offering a broad selection of high-quality wines from around the world that strikes a balance between quality and value. These prominently include lesser-known vintages from small wineries in the local area and unusual or little-known wine regions. City Wine Merchant also boasts a small but growing selection of old and rare wines sourced from private cellars.

Locally-owned since 1893, Buffalo Optical is the citys longest-standing business of its kind, reliably providing Western New Yorkers with a full range of products and services such as designer eyeglasses (including frames from such well-loved brands as Ralph Lauren Polo, Versace, Anne Klein, Liz Claiborne, and DKNY at surprisingly reasonable prices), contact lenses, reading glasses and magnifiers, and related paraphernalia, as well as repairing damaged frames and providing comprehensive eye exams and screenings for optical maladies like glaucoma and cataracts. Buffalo Optical is well-loved among area residents for the extraordinarily attentive and dedicated service they provide to each customer.

In business in the Theater District since 1972, owner Lou Montesano has built Lincoln Coin Stamps renown with collectors from all over the city and region with his honesty, integrity, and friendly and helpful service to his customers. A wide and changing selection of coins and stamps of all descriptions are available, as are supplies and accessories for the collector. Appraisal service is also available. Despite Lincoln Coin Stamps downtown location, ample free parking is available!

Opened in 2010, Soul Tattoo is located on Delaware Avenue just north of the Chippewa Street entertainment district. Soul Tattoo offers full-spectrum custom tattooing in a sterile environment duly licensed by the New York State Department of Health. All major credit cards are accepted.

The second location of the upscale boutique of the same name that has made such a splash on Hertel Avenue has been in business at the Hotel Lafayette since 2012. In contrast to the focus of the original room on luxury furniture and housewares, room2 places more of an emphasis on quality gifts, many of which are locally-themed: quirky items such as buffalo-shaped bottle openers and throw pillows with the geographical coordinates of the city printed on them are a great way for visitors to downtown to commemorate their visit to Buffalo. A modest array of accessories such as scarves and jewelry are also on offer, and the typical stock in trade of the Hertel Avenue location is not neglected either: interestingly, many of the same upscale furnishings found in the Hotel Lafayettes guest rooms upstairs are available for sale at room2. As with the original room, the items at room2 are high-end and priced accordingly—the aforementioned throw pillows sell for upwards of $100—so do not expect any bargains here.
At the Hotel Lafayette; Metro Rail: Lafayette Square

Ricks Sports Apparel has been, in their own words, "Allentowns Athletic Footwear Store Since 1984". Shoes are the main stock in trade here—the newest and best from brands like Nike, Timberland, and K-Swiss—but Ricks also carries athletic apparel like Champion tracksuits and jogging pants, New Era caps, as well as track and dugout jackets.

Launched in June 2011 in the heart of Allentown, Glorias No Limit offers "classy, dressy, affordable, and comfortable" womens apparel including dresses, jeans, jewelry and accessories aimed at stylish yet active urbanites. Glorias also sells a range of body lotions, oils, and other goods.
Metro Bus 7, 11 or 25; Metro Rail: Allen-Medical Campus

Located on Elmwood Avenue just north of Allen Street, Lionel Lucas small but greatly interesting boutique offers a full range of African apparel, accessories, and jewelry. Dashikis, kaftans, and robes including agbada and boubous are stocked, as well as ethnic textiles such as batik, damask, and mudcloth, often in muted yet vibrant colors. In addition, Flight 104 also sells a variety of African crafts and incense. Simply put, one of Allentowns most interesting shopping destinations.

A new store owned and operated by Katherin Hughes, a certified beautician who does double duty as a stylist at New Touch of Elegance, the salon next door owned by her family, KFashions stock in trade is fashionable and contemporary womens clothing, shoes and accessories with an urban accent. KFashions staff is fully bilingual in Spanish and English and they take pride in providing friendly and personalized service to each customer.

A purveyor of "beautiful clothing for interesting women", the Dress Shop is the place to go in Allentown for creative and chic clothing and accessories at reasonable prices, from such brands as Kiko, Anthropologie, and Cut Loose, as well as by new designers on the cutting edge of fashion whose lines are displayed on the stores website.
Metro Bus 7, 11 or 25; Metro Rail: Allen-Medical Campus
M-Fr 10:30AM-6PM, first F of each month till 9PM, Sa 10AM-6PM, Su noon-5PM

Recently moved to Allentown from its former location in downtown Lockport , in the words of its website, "the idea of Picasso Moon isnt just to be a groovy boutique, but to be a groovy experience!" A wide range of unique, hard-to-find t-shirts is stocked here, with band tees, hoodies and hats a particular specialty. As well, womens clothes, accessories such as wallets and belts, jewelry, gifts and novelties are available, all sold for affordable prices by a friendly and attentive staff.

Established in 2002, Krudmart was one of the original pioneers of the newly hip West Side shopping district of Grant-Ferry before "moving on up" in late 2012, to the storefront next to Fugazi near the corner of Franklin and Allen Streets. The selection of clothing and gear at this popular shop is a high-quality array of limited-edition urban streetwear. Designs indebted to the hip-hop, skateboarding, and street art cultures are hand-selected by the stores dedicated owners such that only the most unique aesthetics and highest-quality pieces are offered. There are some great finds here—after a year of fruitless searching, this author found an original-edition Montreal Expos baseball cap there at a great price. As the multitude of Krudmart stickers youll find around the Elmwood Village and near UB will attest, this is a popular place among Buffalos college crowd.
Metro Bus 7, 11 or 25; Metro Rail: Allen-Medical Campus
Black Cat Vintage is a highly regarded Allen Street institution that sells a wide range of vintage clothing, jewelry and accessories for men and women.
Metro Bus 7, 11 or 25; Metro Rail: Allen-Medical Campus

Housed in the understated yet lovely Art Deco-style Buffalo Design Collaborative Building, Avenue Art Frame is a well-loved Allentown institution that specializes in custom framing of original art and prints. Avenue Art Frames professional staff take great care to help customers pick out the right frame and matte boards for each individual piece. Avenue also sells pre-framed prints that trend heavily toward work by local artists as well as vintage postcards and posters of Buffalo scenes.
Metro Bus 11, 25 or 29; Metro Rail: Allen-Medical Campus

El Buen Amigo—"The Good Friend" in Spanish—is the name of the storefront gallery in Allentown run by the Latin-American Cultural Association of Buffalo. Aside from the works of art that are on display and for sale in the gallery, El Buen Amigo also hosts a wide variety of activities and programs reflective of the vibrancy of the local Hispanic community, including music, cultural enrichment programs, and Spanish language classes. El Buen Amigo also offers fair-trade crafts, clothing, and coffee for sale.

Studio Hart is the brainchild of Daniel and Barbara Hart, whose lifelong dream of operating a small contemporary art gallery has been realized with this charming space in the heart of Allentown. In addition to the gallery space which features the work of the owners as well as exhibitions by artists from the local area, Studio Hart doubles as the working studio of owner Barbara Hart, whose jewelry and wooden figurines take a prominent place among the displayed works. Musical performances and poetry readings in the adjacent Café 59 are held frequently; and greeting cards, jewelry, and other unique merchandise is offered for sale.
Metro Bus 7, 11 or 25; Metro Rail: Allen-Medical Campus
Tu-F 11:30AM-3:30PM, first F of each month also 6PM-9PM, Sa noon-4PM, also by appointment

Since 1985, Buffalo Big Prints focus has been the production of custom prints for such industries as fine art, advertising, and pre-press. A wide variety of specialty films and papers are used, such as digital photobase papers of the highest quality, artists canvas, and 100% cotton rag papers. As well, services such as high-resolution digital image capture, digital restoration and enhancements, and custom finishing are provided to local artists. Buffalo Big Print also boasts a large gallery where the work of many local artists is displayed.
Metro Bus 7, 11 or 25; Metro Rail: Allen-Medical Campus

Founded in 2006, B West Studios is the project of local artist Peter Caruso. B Wests airy, inviting gallery space displays an eclectic range of works by between seven and ten local artists at a time, with an emphasis on the work of new faces in the local art community as well as students, and with a view to selling affordable yet high-quality work generally priced at $400 per piece or less. Special exhibits are held on a monthly basis.

Situated in a breathtaking three-story French Second Empire-style house at the corner of Virginia and Franklin Streets that dates to 1870, Dana Tillou Fine Arts is a combination art gallery and antique shop that specializes in American and British paintings from the 19th and early 20th Centuries, folk art, and 19th-century English antique furniture. Dana Tillou also has over 47 years of experience in professionally appraising art and antiques for insurance, estate, or personal purposes. In addition to works for sale, Dana Tillous art gallery features a variety of works by artists from Buffalo and the surrounding region, including works by such locally famous names as Martha Vissert Hooft, Carlo Nisita, and Evelyn Rumsey Cary.
Metro Bus 11, 25 or 29; Metro Rail: Allen-Medical Campus

Founded in 1959 by graphic artist Charles W. Hyatt, Western New Yorks leading purveyor of art supplies now boasts two additional locations in Clarence and suburban Rochester as well as their original one in Allentown. In addition to such supplies as oil, acrylic and watercolor paints, brushes, canvas, pens, inks, papers, easels, ad nauseam, Hyatts also offers picture framing services, classes and workshops, and miscellaneous gifts. Hyatts is also a regional leader in the field of computer signmaking and is one of the worlds leading distributors of Pantone color-matching products.
Metro Bus 7, 8 or 29; Metro Rail: Allen-Medical Campus

"Top Dollar Paid On the Spot" is the credo at Larrys Antiques. Since 1980, a wide range of unique and interesting antiques and collectibles has been on display and for sale at this charming store on Elmwood Avenue. Items such as fancy leaded glass and lamps, clocks, garden items, cabinets and furniture of all types are specialties at Larrys.

A frequent winner in the "Best Antique Shop" category in Artvoices annual "Best of Buffalo" poll, the Antique Mans specialty is music: LPs, cassettes, and CDs hang in the window and occupy a prominent place on the shelves here, with timeless classics from the likes of Jimi Hendrix, Bob Dylan, and Frank Sinatra for sale or even playing on the turntable in the store. As well, the Antique Man stocks a quirky selection of books, pamphlets, magazines, comic books, art, and miscellaneous trinkets to accompany the records.

Founded in 1978 by its eponymous owner, Carl Slone, and located in an 1883 wood-frame Stick-style house, LÉté Antiques specalizes in a wide variety of gas and early electric light fixtures, with a particular emphasis on Art Nouveau, Art Deco, and Sheffield-style chandeliers and sconces, as well as stained and leaded glass of all varieties. Restoration and estate consultations are also offered.

Antiques Allentown is a funky shop thats housed in an unmissable white and pink cottage on Elmwood Avenue just north of Allen Street. Specializing in primitives as well as small items from the 1960s and earlier, Antiques Allentown stocks antiques and collectibles for all budgets in a friendly environment. Layaway and estate management is also offered.

Simply put, Rust Belt Books is one of the best, and best-loved, used bookstores in Buffalo or anywhere else. An exhaustive selection of reading material of every genre—from old cookbooks to 70s music journalism to esoteric feminist essays to the classics of literature—is available there for the book lover, and the enthusiastic and helpful staff and colorful clientele are all Allentown to the hilt. More than that, Rust Belt Books relentless devotion to the local community sees them playing host to a variety of community events, as well as poetry readings, plays and other special events.

Divine Machine Tattoo is the brainchild of Cory Cudney, perhaps the most renowned tattoo artist ever to hail from Buffalo: his work was featured in Mike DeVries book "Tattoo Prodigies", and the wait for an appointment with Cory himself (at the downtown location) can be months long. Nonetheless, the stable of acclaimed professional artists who staff Divine Machine are among the best Western New York has to offer, offering extensive consultations with the customer to work out tattoo ideas and plying their trade in a safe and pleasant environment.

Chuck and Seth are the tattooists who staff this friendly and safe Elmwood Avenue tattoo studio; these two locally renowned artists are equally as happy to book an appointment and answer any question customers may have as they are advising them on the best rockabilly bars and retro clothing stores around town. Faith in Ink employs a professional piercing artist, as well. Cash only.

Founded by Buffalo State College alum Paul Bierker, CowPok has garnered a reputation as Buffalos favorite piercing studio, having won more awards in its category in Artvoices annual "Best of Buffalo" poll than any other. CowPok provides its customers with a friendly, laid-back, clean, and safe experience, and sources its jewelry from some of the best suppliers around. In 2006, CowPok hired its first tattoo artist and has since gone on to similar acclaim as home to some of Buffalos best tattooists.

Opened in 2012, owner Toni Meldzuk named this Elmwood Avenue storefront in honor of the excited feeling she had upon returning to her re-energized hometown after five years living in Savannah . This upbeat positivity reflects itself over all aspects of Coming Home Buffalos identity: its not only a retail store where such a diversity of items are sold as jewelry, incense burners, essential oils, leather-bound journals, whimsical gifts, and crafts and works of visual art by local residents, but also as a forum for events such as aromatherapy classes, art shows, holistic health demonstrations, massage therapy sessions, and a wide variety of other community programs and groups.

The Rooster and Two Chicks is the brainchild of three old friends who, like more and more Buffalo natives, found themselves moved back after many years away, unable to resist the appeal of their hometown. Equal parts retail bakery and gift shop, sold here is an appetizing—and aromatic—selection of fresh baked goods made on-premises from scratch. Standing out among a delicious array of cupcakes, cookies, and brownies (including copious gluten-free options) is an incredibly creative array of breads—everything from banana Nutella to lemon tea. The gift-shop end of the business is a cluttered yet airy space where a wide variety of quirky tchotchkes are sold, with an emphasis on decorative knick-knacks for the home and inexpensive original art. Best of all, co-owner Smiths experience in the cutthroat world of New York City retail has inspired him to add The Rooster and Two Chicks to a growing list of Allentown businesses that are open evenings and weekends, bucking the traditional scenario of limited, sometimes irregular hours.
Metro Bus 7, 11 or 25; Metro Rail: Allen-Hospital

Located on Elmwood Avenue just south of Allen Street, HeadSpace is Allentowns premier "head shop", stocking a wide variety of scientific glass pipes, artistic and decorative glassware, vaporizers, and other smoking accessories, as well as (interestingly enough) a modest selection of baseball caps.

The Allen Street Connection is a pleasant shop that deals in unique fashion accessories and other gift items with an African flair. Aside from the hand-crafted necklaces, beads, bangles, earring, sterling silver rings, and other jewelry that are available (including customized items offered on a made-to-order basis), the Allen Street Connection features a selection of Afrocentric literature, handbags and other accessories, toiletry items such as shea butter and essential oils, and hand-carved art imported from Mali , Senegal , Ghana and elsewhere. The owner, Lonnie, is a friendly and interesting fellow whos always game for a chat about politics, art, or current events, and often hosts readings of poetry and literature in his shop.
Metro Bus 7, 11 or 25; Metro Rail: Allen-Medical Campus

Elmwood Discount Liquor Wine opened in summer 2011, when Singh Lakhi purchased Claiborne Liquors, open for over forty years in a storefront a few doors down Elmwood Avenue, and moved the business to the larger location it boasts today. A full range of liquors, wines, and other beverages are offered at this festively decorated store near the corner of North Street, with occasional events held including tastings of Upstate New York wines.

One of the first "package stores" to reopen in Buffalo after the repeal of Prohibition, the erstwhile Days Park Liquor has been reborn as Spirits of Allentown, a wine store located directly on "The Bend", at the west end of the Allen Street strip. Open until midnight daily except Sunday (much later than other such stores in Buffalo), a mind-boggling variety of vintages are on offer at this longstanding neighborhood staple, curated by a staff whose knowledge of wine is second to none in the Buffalo area. A small selection of other liquors are also sold in a bohemian ambience that is classic Allentown.

P.L.U.M. Works is the collaboration of Ellen Markel and Christopher Bretschneider, a longstanding team of talented artisans who came to Buffalo in 1999 after a decade working together in Shoreham, Vermont. Today, P.L.U.M. Works is the place to go for 100% original wooden furniture that is traditional yet unique, and custom-designed in full partnership and collaboration with the client. Those who come to P.L.U.M. Works can know that their table, bed, desk, case, chair, or other piece is crafted artfully from scratch, and no other piece of furniture is identical to it. These two do truly magnificent work.

More than just another antique furniture store, Shop 43 is a place where the retro-vintage vibe plays into every aspect of its identity—hipsters will be in mid-century-modern heaven fawning over far more bold and colorful versions of usual suspects like sofas, table sets, and lamps, and even more offbeat items like retro TV sets and vintage black and white bar stools. Best of all, owner Jessica Petrella keeps it all laid-back, with prices a good deal more affordable than the furniture stores on Hertel Avenue and with far less pushy salespeople to boot.
Metro Bus 7, 11 or 25; Metro Rail: Allen-Medical Campus

Newly opened and already making a splash in Allentown, Ziggy Starfish proudly provides Buffalo residents with an affordable, sustainable, and environmentally-friendly alternative to shoddy mass-market furniture. After a careful selection process of unique used furniture, light fixtures, housewares and other items of high quality and in a variety of styles (from antique to retro to contemporary), the exceptionally skilled staff then refinish and restore the pieces to their former splendor, and sell the finished product to customers at fair prices. A booming secondary business at Ziggy Starfish is the support of Buffalos arts community through the selling of original works of art and decorative items created by local artists and artisans.

A component of the Buffalo Design Collaborative, Nest Interiors was founded by Brooke Pelc, a Buffalo State College graduate who sees her hometown as (to quote a recent write-up in Buffalo Rising) "a great canvas to work with", onto which she and her talented staff "paint" their truly innovative and lovely design ideals. Nest Interiors retail store on Delaware Avenue sells a bevy of unique and original furniture, window treatments and other interior elements, with employees on hand to help customers brainstorm ideas on interior design and space planning using conceptual rendering and other state-of-the-art technology.
Metro Bus 11, 25 or 29; Metro Rail: Allen-Medical Campus

Connie Cavanaughs Très Beau Interiors is located on Delaware Avenues Midway, a block of posh row houses of the type that is commonly seen in East Coast cities such as New York and Philadelphia , but is comparatively rare in Buffalo. Amid this architectural splendor can be found the splendor of some of the highest-quality contemporary and traditional furnishings, lighting elements, garden decor, and other interior elements in Buffalo. More than just a store, however, Très Beau Interiors staff has almost thirty years of experience working with their clients every step of the way in crafting the optimum interior space in terms of aesthetics, individual needs and budget.
Metro Bus 11, 25 or 29; Metro Rail: Allen-Medical Campus

Located on Allen Street since 2010, Ricks Cycle Shop is actually the countrys second-oldest independent cycle shop in continuous operation, opened in 1898 on Main Street downtown by brothers Frederick, Otto, and Thomas Rick. In fact, Buffalo native Albert Krushel, who helped the American time trial team to a bronze medal in the 1912 Olympics in Stockholm , rode a bicycle from Ricks. Today, Ricks stocks new and used bicycles from such well-respected brands as Diamondback, Haro, Redline, SE, Torker, and Fuji, and is one of the top 100 dealers of Raleigh bicycles in the nation. Professional staff are on hand to recommend the right bike for each customers individual preferences and needs. In addition, Ricks also carries clothing, gear and accessories such as helmets, bicycle shorts, patches, pumps and tool kits, lights and reflectors, and water bottles.
Metro Bus 7, 11 or 25; Metro Rail: Allen-Medical Campus

Accurately describing itself as "a refreshing alternative to chain stores and traditional quilt shops", Elmwood Village Fabrics is a one-stop shop in Allentown (dont let the name confuse you!) for reasonably-priced fabric for curtains, clothes, quilts, and all other needs, as well as accessories and implements such as buttons, thread, needles, and even a small selection of sewing machines. Elmwood Village Fabrics also sells decorative items pre-made from fabrics that are available in the store.
Metro Bus 7, 11 or 25; Metro Rail: Allen-Medical Campus

The self-proclaimed "best florist choice in Buffalo", Bloom Floristry takes great pride in carefully selecting the most beautiful and freshest flowers for their customers arrangements. Aside from bouquets, Bloom offers a wide array of potted plants, terrariums, and other products, and is happy to prepare displays for weddings, anniversaries, birthdays, and other special events.
Metro Bus 7, 8 or 29; Metro Rail: Allen-Medical Campus

This unique urban optical boutique is an integral part of the emerging business district along Main Street between Virginia and Allen that has come to be known as the "Edge of Allentown". Dr. Bob Hornberger and his talented staff are equally disposed to introducing customers to their selection of fashionable eyeframes and sunglasses in various styles (including well-known lines such as Gucci, Dolce Gabbana, Ray-Ban, and Versace), adjusting and repairing existing frames, and administering comprehensive eye examinations in-store.
Metro Bus 7 or 8; Metro Rail: Allen-Medical Campus

Gina Vallones vintage clothing store on West Utica Street between Elmwood and Delaware Avenues was described in a write-up in Buffalo Rising as being "just like the merchandise that youll find inside—obscure and definitely not on the main drag". A quirky selection of handpicked vintage and consignment clothing for women can be found in the front room of this old house, jumbled but amazingly wide-ranging and just waiting for bargain hunters to comb through. Shoes and accessories are a specialty at Ragamuffins, and the sign on the door that reads "we buy and sell Dior, Pucci, LV, Lilly, St. John, Gucci and Chanel" is no exaggeration—there are some great bargains to be found here on designer items.

One of several galleries and studios in the emerging neighborhood that has come to be called Midtown, Kepa3 Gallery is the latest venture of artist Peter Fowler, who came to Buffalo in 2001 after spending time in Spain , absorbing the influences of the rich artistic tradition of such luminaries as Diego Velazquez and Bartolomé Murillo. At Kepa3 are displayed and sold not only Fowlers own original oil paintings, sculptures, and mixed-media works, but also handmade jewelry by local artisan Kathi Roussel as well as works by various other Buffalo artists.
M by appointment, Tu F 11AM-5PM, W 11AM-4PM, Th 11AM-3PM, Sa 11AM-3:30PM

Curated by Donald J. Siuta, a noted artist, educator and consultant who also serves on the Board of Directors of the Buffalo Arts Commission and as head of the Western New York Artists Group, the Art Dialogue Gallery exhibits a small but magnificent collection of paintings, drawings, photographs, sculptures, and works in other media by local artists. In addition, there are antique prints for sale, and Siuta puts his nearly forty years of experience to good use in offering the most comprehensive selection of custom framing in Western New York, with hundreds of mouldings to choose from.
Metro Bus 11 or 25; Metro Rail: Summer-Best

The newest location of this small local chainlet opened in the Oxford area in 2010. Though a vast array of used books on a wide variety of subjects, vinyl records, old toys, and other items are for sale, its their main stock in trade that led a Buffalo Rising contributor to describe Book Outlet More as the "Fort Knox of comics". Indeed, at Book Outlet More can be found a vast, well-organized bounty of comic books of all genres purchased in bulk by the owner at auctions and through other means; by his estimation there are over 100,000 titles onsite at any given time, including 20,000 on the sales floor. Despite the ponderous bulk of their inventory, Book Outlet Mores staff does an excellent job ensuring that collectors are offered only high-quality, well-sought-after comic books in good condition and at reasonable prices.
Metro Bus 8; Metro Rail: Delavan-Canisius College

Record Theatre—whose original location on Main Street in the Delaware District has been open since 1976—is one of the only locally-owned record stores remaining in Buffalo today, which some might say is reason enough in itself to stop in. Record Theatre boasts nearly 20,000 square feet of new and previously-owned CDs, DVDs, and vinyl records, with a still-impressive selection especially in terms of hip-hop, RB, and other urban music genres. Record Theatre will also purchase your used CDs or specially order from their distributors any title that is not in stock.
Metro Bus 8, 18 or 26; Metro Rail: Delavan-Canisius College

Family-owned and operated for nearly 75 years, Gates Circle Wine Liquor is one of Buffalos favorite purveyors of wines of all kind, specializing in rare and high-end vintages stored in their own controlled-temperature room to ensure the highest quality. Gates Circle Wine Liquor hosts free wine tastings weekly that feature the best local wines from the Finger Lakes and the Niagara Peninsula , and their knowledgeable staff can even advise on the best wine to pair with a special meal you are planning. Gates Circle Wine Liquor also offers a large selection of domestic and imported spirits to suit all tastes.

An immensely popular neighborhood flower shop owned for years by the inimitable Fann Markel, in the words of its website, The Floristry is "committed to offering only the finest floral arrangements and gifts, backed by service that is friendly and prompt". To that end, The Floristry offers pre-made bouquets or customized arrangements of fresh, dried and silk flowers, potted plants, tropical plants, and terrariums. In addition, an array of gifts and other items such as greeting cards, candles, and gift baskets of various types are offered. The Floristrys professional staff is always on hand to answer any questions customers might have, and delivery service is available to most locations in the metro area.
Shop for fresh produce, organics; music, family friendly. Open Sundays.
Shop for bedding plants, shrubs, hanging baskets, garden supplies, Christmas trees and wreaths. All varieties of vegetables. Open daily.

Luxurious yet affordable menswear is the order of the day at Richel Formalwear. With a skillful and genuine approach to customer service honed over more than a quarter-century of experience, owner Carmelo Bandinelli attends to Buffalonians in search of elegant mens formal attire such as tuxedos, dress shirts, vests, three-piece suits, shoes, and accessories such as hats, ties, and cufflinks. The owner himself performs each custom fitting with a trained eye to perfection thats unmatched in the area, and also offers customized tailoring and alterations including jacket tapering. Richel Formalwear doesnt leave the opposite sex out in the cold, either: wedding dresses, bridesmaids gowns, prom dresses, and other formal attire for ladies are available for sale or rent.

Blue Collar Buffalo is a brand-new source for mens clothing and accessories thats operated jointly by the retail forces behind two nearby Hertel Avenue mainstays, room and Modern Nostalgia. The style here, inspired by Buffalos rough-and-tumble industrial history, is contemporary and stylish yet rugged and masculine, comprising well-known brands and upstart new designers alike. The store itself, with an ambience thats airy and chic yet rustic, fits the mood perfectly.

The first thing a customer may think upon entering Peek-a-Boo Baby Boutique might be that for a storefront that looks so small from the outside and is so packed with merchandise, it has a remarkably airy, expansive feel, clean and cheerily decorated. Once that first impression is over, the customer may very well marvel at the large and adorable selection of previously-enjoyed items for children from newborns through toddlers—clothes, high chairs, bassinets, strollers, toys, and miscellaneous merchandise—all in impeccable condition. Most of the merchandise is consigned to the store by parents of growing children (call for details), but there are also some new items as well, much of which is the unique work of local designers. All items are 10% off after 5PM on Wednesday.

Modern Nostalgia is a cute womens clothing boutique owned by Nikki Polasik and Brianne Klejdys-Long, a pair of lifelong friends who are described on the stores website as "Buffalo all-stars when it comes to style and fashion". The "style" in question takes equal inspiration from elegant classic designs and exciting contemporary looks from up-and-coming designers—hence the name of the store—and makes the owners infectious love of fashion all the more obvious. Customers adore Modern Nostalgia—and forgive their somewhat high prices—because of their wide and changing selection of clothes (ranging from formalwear to more casual designs), lingerie, jewelry and accessories. The last two on that list are a particular specialty, with a massive range of earrings, bracelets, necklaces, handbags and clutches from collections by local and national designers, such as Pura Vida, Ornamental Things, and Made By Anatomy.

Déjà Lu is renowned around Buffalo for its great (and affordable) selection of fashionable dresses, formalwear, formal and casual jewelry, handbags, and accessories, all of which are united by a quirky, stylish, fashion-forward aesthetic all their own. Déjà Lus owner, Louise Abbinanti, has a background not only in retail but also in many other areas of the fashion industry, including as a designer, fabric-cutter, and custom seamstress. Accordingly, in this charming Hertel Avenue boutique can be found a mixture of name-brand items (including a few brands that are exclusive to Déjà Lu) as well as the owners own designs. To top it all off, visitors enjoy a bright and inviting environment in which to browse the unique selections here.
Tu-W Sa noon-6PM, Th-F noon-8PM, also by appointment

Locally owned and operated since 2011, Chic and Sweet brings the latest high-fashion designer clothing from the streets of New York , Los Angeles , and Europes power centers to the heart of the Hertel Avenue shopping district. Co-owners Zack and Annemarie Schneiders years of experience in marketing and retail, respectively, guide them in carefully selecting an impeccable gamut of pieces—blouses, dresses, blazers, pants, sweaters, jewelry, and accessories—to a discriminating and fashion-conscious public in search of items that are trendy and elegant, yet a bit more conservative than what they might find on Elmwood. As well, an interesting and quirky selection of kitchenware and miscellaneous gifts, often with a local theme, are sold. Chic and Sweet was honored as Buffalos "Best New Business" for 2012 by Buffalo Spree magazine.

Diva Style boasts the self-proclaimed "best ladies shoes in town", but in fact, this lovely store, situated near the east end of the Hertel strip, actually sells a wide gamut of shoes, boots, jewelry, and other accessories in a lively, sassy urban style. A range of mens jewelry is also offered.

P.S. Accessories boasts cute and fashion-forward clothes for all tastes, including plus sizes—but as the stores name implies, the star of the show here is the ample and ever-changing selection of jewelry, handbags, hairbands, leggings, belts, and other accessories, representing a style that encompasses diverse influences to suit all tastes, yet is distinctive and cohesive. The new items that constantly arrive at P.S. ensure that theres always a fresh slate of trendy items for shoppers to pore over. Best of all, the staff earns rave reviews for the friendly and helpful care they take of their guests, and the prices here cant be beat—the stores policy is never to charge more than $40 for any item!
Tu Sa noon-5PM, W F noon-6PM, Th 11AM-5PM

A brand-new gallery opened in 2012 to great fanfare, Meridian Wests owners, George Grace and Nancy Clarke Mariani, are both active members of the Buffalo Society of Artists and boast long and illustrious pedigrees in Buffalos arts community (as a writer/artist and the chair of Lancaster High Schools art department, respectively). Their work is on display and available for sale in Meridian Wests airy, minimalist exhibit space, as are paintings, sculptures and mixed-media works by other local and regional artists such as Gary Wolfe, Ann Gunderman, and Rita Argen Auerbach. A small selection of gifts is available for those of a creative disposition. In addition, theatrical and musical performances, poetry readings, art and writing classes, and community events of all types are frequently held at Meridian West.

The credo here is, "We may not be big, but were small"—and so it is at State of the Art, where the staff consists of Mar Penner Griswold, a certified picture framer with over 40 years of experience in the field, and her ever-present feline companion, Lucy. Since 1982, State of the Art has been a Hertel Avenue mainstay, with the stores website vaunting a full range of services including framing, frame repair, photographic repair and restoration, matting, glass replacement, and—yes—cat advice. Customers rave about Griswolds helpful advice on style and color, patient and sincere service to her clients, and fair prices.

Opened in 1988 as a small art gallery and frame store at the heart of the Hertel Avenue corridor, The Main Frame is a sister shop to the venerable Vern Stein Art Frame in Williamsville, and serves also as the production facility for the custom-made frames sold at both stores. The Main Frame boasts a large selection of prints on display and for sale, with antique prints featuring local scenes and themes a particular specialty. The Main Frames staff has over 30 years of combined experience in custom framing, and really does a marvelous job at it.

Opened in 1998 on the West Side and moved to its current location four years later, Greg Link is the self-taught craftsman whose sculpture and handmade pottery can be found among the unique items for sale and on display in Cone Five Potterys ample gallery space. The balance of the items here encompass works by over 50 artists from all over Buffalo and Western New York, in media as diverse as painting, jewelry, metal and wood art, photography, and blown glass, as well as occasional temporary exhibitions. In addition, open studio time for gallery members takes place at Cone Five every Thursday, Saturday and Sunday from noon till 9PM, and Donna Goeckel Martiny and Rachel Kofahl conduct pottery classes that range from basic skills like hand building, trimming and glazing to advanced techniques.

This is a great place to pick up art supplies, with pens, brushes, paints, easels and sketchbooks delighting beginner and advanced artists alike. However, the service that has made The Artery so highly regarded among the arts community in Buffalo is the custom framing effected for their customers on all manner of prints, posters, diplomas, photographs, certificates, and other items. The Arterys 25 years of experience affords them the ability to do framing thats near museum quality. Additionally, the seasoned professionals that staff this venerable Hertel Avenue institution are happy to advise customers on decorative ideas to accentuate their framed works.

The Webb Trading Company is a massive emporium of furniture and interior decorative items in the heart of North Buffalo that boasts 2,000 square feet (184m²) of genuine period antiques in a wide variety of styles, as well as modern reproductions. Along with the myriad furnishings, decorative items, and objets dart offered for sale there, the Webb Trading Company also employs decorators who custom-design clients interior spaces and manages estate sale liquidations and auctions from which they (as well as Sempre Vintage, the store-within-a-store where Anna Kaplan sells sophisticated vintage ladies clothing from the 50s to the 80s) source their merchandise.
W-F 11AM-5PM, Sa noon-4PM, and by appointment
The Antique Lamp Company and Gift Emporium

The Antique Lamp Company is where, since 1997, longtime antique aficionado John Tobin has offered for sale a full selection of antique and vintage lamps and light fixtures in 19th- and early 20th-century styles such as Victorian, Art Nouveau, Art Deco, Mission, and Art Moderne. Western New Yorks only full-time, professional lamp restorer, Tobins work in repairing and polishing these pieces to restore their former brillians truly betrays the boundless love he has for what he does. A wide variety of fine china, timepieces, jewelry and accessories, flowers and gifts round out the offerings at the Antique Lamp Company. The cherry on top is the decor, whose opulent elegance extends to the soft music and subtle fragrances that delight customers as they shop.

Dealing in a wide selection of wholesale antique furniture, timepieces, china, sterling silver, light fixtures, and decorative accessories, Buffalo Antiques is a massive emporium thats been in business on Hertel for over fifteen years. In addition to the antique items, which represent Victorian and 19th-century European styles through the Mid-Century Modern period, a variety of new furniture is also sold here: Buffalo Antiques is a licensed dealer of the Maitland-Smith and LaBarge brands. As well, these fine folks are always on the lookout for quality items to purchase, from single items to partial and total estate sale liquidations. Buffalo Antiques offers free estate sale consultations and fair-market appraisals of antique items.

One of the most popular of Hertels many destinations for antiquers, the Stock Exchange deals mainly in antique and retro (and some new) furniture, light fixtures, and miscellaneous decor in a friendly atmosphere thats refreshingly devoid of the usual antique-store snootiness. As the Stock Exchanges merchandise is sourced mainly from the estate sales whose management is the business other main raison dêtre, the inventory here is diverse and in constant flux. In the midst of it all is owner Andrew Gay, who curates this ever-changing menagerie with an astounding degree of knowledge and skill.

Owner Frank Scheuttle has a long history in every aspect of the world of arts and antiques: well-versed in art history and theory thanks to his M.A. in American Folk Culture from the New York State Historical Associations Cooperstown Graduate Program, and tempered in the business side of the field with 40 years of experience as a collector, consultant, dealer, and museum curator. Silent Voices, his Hertel Avenue storefront and gallery space, contains a wide selection of artworks, quilts, crafts, and antiques on display and for sale that represent all facets of the Americana that is the object of his encyclopedic knowledge, boundless enthusiasm, and genuine love.

The selection at this small used book shop directly across from the North Park Theater may not be the widest, but the Second Reader makes up for that with the quality of its merchandise and the friendliness and enthusiasm of its staff—not to mention the surprising and unusual finds that can often be encountered on the shelves there. The Second Readers excellent prices are exemplified by the "$1 Book Table" which makes regular apperances in season on the sidewalk in front of the store. In addition to books, a range of prints, gifts and other ephemera are available here.

Eaton Chocolate has been in business since 2010, selling a huge variety of sweet treats made with chocolate handcrafted directly on the premises, making for what is undoubtedly the freshest chocolate in the Buffalo area. The range of confections sold at Eaton spans traditional favorites such as truffles and turtles, to local specialties like sponge candy and orange chocolate, to oddities such as chocolate-covered bacon on a stick. Owner Ingeri Eaton got her start making fresh chocolate on her stovetop for family, friends and coworkers, and soon found herself getting busier each week whipping up custom orders for her acquaintances special events. This emphasis on customization carries over to her shop, where in addition to the pre-made products, customers can choose from a range of ingredients à la carte to combine into a seemingly endless gamut of treats. Eatons helpful and friendly staff is the icing on the (chocolate) cake.
Metro Bus 8 or 23; Metro Rail: LaSalle
Tu-W 11AM-7PM, Th 11AM-9PM, F noon-6PM, Sa noon-9PM, Su 1PM-5PM

The name of the game at Bella Mia is rekindling the memories of nostalgic customers with "retro candies" from their childhoods. For sale here are old-school favorites like Laffy Taffy, Lemonheads, Necco wafers, and Abba Zabba chocolate bars, Cadbury and Mars candy bars that are imported from Canada and especially popular with customers from north of the border, and delectable oversize lollipops of the kind that will remind customers of a certain age of summers at Crystal Beach . Other confections such as licorice, chocolate truffles, and bubble gum are available as well—and what would a candy store in Buffalo be without a huge selection of sponge candy (available in half-pound, one-pound, and two-pound boxes)? An ice cream counter, coffee and cappuccino, and vintage gifts such as Beatles posters and old-fashioned metal Elvis lunchboxes round out the inventory here. Customers rave especially about Tom, the friendly, down-to-earth owner who always makes sure every visitor to Bella Mia leaves happy.

A local business thats already well-loved and well-established in the Elmwood Village, this second location of the venerable Village Beer Merchant opened in 2012. To put it succinctly, this place is heaven for Buffalo beer snobs. As is perhaps obvious, the specialty here is a slate of brews that gives the perennial favorite local beer store, Premier Gourmet, a run for its money: a dizzying gamut of imports, local and regional microbrews, and seasonal selections curated by a knowledgeable and friendly staff eager to direct customers toward the beer thats right for them. More than that, though, the Village Beer Merchant is a destination for those in search of a wide variety of gourmet specialty foods, with a range of artisanal cheeses, fine olive oils, chocolates, teas, Boars Head deli meats and other charcuterie, and other upscale edibles.

Located at the corner of Hertel and Parker Avenues since 1988, the aptly named Hertel-Parker Liquor Store bucks the usual local trend of stores of this type: customers prefer the massive variety, range and quality of the liquors here to the more modest range of wines. Nonetheless, this independent business is renowned for the friendly and helpful staff that curates the selection. A sticking point among locals is that the owners seem to regard the opening hours as more of a suggestion than a hard-and-fast rule.
Metro Bus 8 or 23; Metro Rail: LaSalle

Since 1960, Johnnys Meats has offered for sale a full range of meats, cold cuts, and cheeses, many of which are produced locally. Johnnys homemade Italian sausage, crafted with a secret blend of herbs and cheeses, is a specialty, but its also just the beginning of the story—this real, old-fashioned butcher shop sells it all. Beef, lamb, bacon, veal, locally produced Sahlens hot dogs, seafood, pork, poultry, and delicious homemade meatballs all keep Johnnys loyal customers coming back for more. In another nod to Hertel Avenues status as the epicenter of Buffalos Italian community, a small line of pasta products is also available.

In the heart of Buffalos Little Italy, appropriately enough, is found this delightful old-world food shop that seems to have been plucked from another time. Carusos Italian Imports is a purveyor of delicious yet unpretentious imported foods which has earned more than its share of loyal customers over its 40 years of operation in North Buffalo. Found here is a myriad of delectable Italian specialties such as pasta, cheeses, olives and olive oils, fresh-baked breads, fine charcuterie such as prosciutto and mortadella, and fresh vegetables. The old-fashioned warmth and friendliness exuded by Carusos employees is matched by the prices, which are among the lowest in town for specialty groceries of this type.

Sandy Hofschneider spent many years working as a registered nurse in North Carolina ; this brand-new Hertel Avenue storefront represents the second phase in her professional life, where her efforts at promoting the health and wellness of the community come through the sale of healthy extra-virgin olive oils and balsamic vinegars—and at great prices. Easily the most interesting products sold at the House of Olives are the flavored olive oils, where the imported extra-virgin oils that are also sold plain come infused with the delicious aromas of fresh basil, jalapeño, Meyer lemon, garlic mushroom, and more. Infused vinegars are also sold, with blackberry, raspberry, hickory, and chocolate among the available flavors. Best of all, customers are well attended to at the House of Olives, with the friendly owner always on hand to suggest pairings, share recipes, or—true to form—extol the myriad health benefits of extra-virgin olive oils and balsamic vinegars.

An official distributor of Totally Wicked brand products, Buffalo Vapor Lounge is a one-stop shop for e-cigarettes and other tobacco alternatives for Buffalonians who want to enjoy the pleasurable sensation of smoking while avoiding some of the detrimental health effects of tobacco. Though a wide range of products are sold here, including smoking systems, accessories, and e-liquids in a wide variety of flavors including caramel cappuccino, pumpkin spice, root beer, and kiwi strawberry, Buffalo Vapor Lounge is as much a chill hang-out spot as a store: customers can smoke at the vapor bar, play a game of pool, or relax on the comfy couches in front of a massive big-screen TV. Though some customers quibble about high prices and customer service that is occasionally inattentive, Buffalo Vapor Lounge is a great resource for people who are new to e-cigarettes, and has everything the experienced e-smoker needs—including many products that are sold nowhere else in the area. As their products contain nicotine, Buffalo Vapor Lounges policy of refusing entry to those under the age of 18 is strictly enforced.

The Virgil Avenue Tobacconists slogan proudly declares it to be "where the city smokes", and if local renown is a measure of quality, thats hardly an exaggeration. This one-stop shop just off Hertel offers everything the Buffalo smoking enthusiast could conceivably desire: imported cigarettes, pipes and pipe tobacco, rolling papers, loose cigarette tobacco, and—the main draw—a dizzying range of premium cigars shipped directly from factory to store. Ashton, Hemmingway, Arturo Fuentes, and Cohiba are only a few of the many brands to be found in Virgil Avenues massive walk-in humidor. Also part of the package is the Rocky Patel Lounge, a cigar lounge with a large-screen HDTV, beverages including a complimentary coffee bar, and club-style seating for up to 20 people.

With the west end of the strip anchored by the longtime stalwarts, Terrapin Station and the Virgil Avenue Tobacconist, Hertel Avenue has long been the go-to neighborhood in Buffalo for enthusiasts of tobacco and other smokeables.

Founded in 2010 and self-described as "Buffalos Classiest Body Art Studio", Arboreal Ink goes about its business of creating high-quality custom-designed tattoos and body piercing in an environment that can be described as almost obsessively dedicated to professionalism, hygiene, and the kind of service that earns customers loyalty. Tattooist Greg Sobczak got his start in 2004; with a BA in Fine Arts from the University of Buffalo, Greg doubles as an accomplished oil painter whose work can be found in many area galleries, as well as at Arboreal Ink itself. Piercing artist Brittany Chmura also does double duty: her line of unique custom-designed jewelry is available for sale exclusively at Arboreal Ink. Simply put, no tattoo or piercing enthusiast will leave this place disappointed (or even underwhelmed).
W-F noon-8PM, Sa noon-9PM, Su noon-5PM, or by appointment

The satellite location of MaddTat2, Mark Maddens renowned tattoo parlor in the Elmwood Village, has been in operation in North Buffalo since 2010. Though the staff at the Elmwood location has been earning rave reviews for a long time for their skill and friendliness, its at Madd Tiki where Mark Madden himself performs tattoos in his own custom-designed studio—customers who have been lucky enough to land an appointment with him unanimously laud the unmatched skill and dedication with which he performs his art, as well as the sincere and friendly rapport he builds with each client.
The heart of the Hertel Avenue business district.
